content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

Given a struct `FloatWithUnits` with fields `value` and `unit` (make sure to define it!), write a `show` method for it that will concatenate the value and unit with a space like this "1.8 meters".

```julia
struct FloatWithUnits{T <: Real}
    value::T
    unit::String
end

function Base.show(io::IO, f::FloatWithUnits)
    print(io, "$(f.value) $(f.unit)")
end
```
This `show` method will be called when you try to print an instance of the FloatWithUnits struct. It takes two arguments: `io`, which is the output stream where you want to write your string, and `f::FloatWithUnits`, which is the object that you are printing. The function simply concatenates the value and unit with a space and writes it to `io`.
